awd_titl_txt: Macromolecular, Supramolecular and/or Nanomolecular Photophysics and Photochemistry of d10 and d8 Complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry  program, Mohammad Omary of the University of North Texas (UNT) is developing a new group of compounds for use as catalysts in alternative energy technologies. The compounds serve to accelerate the rate at which water is decomposed to hydrogen and oxygen, releasing the energy that once held the hydrogen and oxygen atoms together in each water molecule. The compounds being developed in this project are expected to have greater stability than existing materials in use, thus extending the practicality of this promising new source of alternative energy. The project is strengthening several existing academic/government/industrial collaborations between UNT and other US universities, national laboratories, and private sector entities as well as some existing and new international collaborations. The research is having a broader impact on energy-related science through the development of promising new technologies.

In this project, a series of phosphorescent complexes with various molecular- and nano-structural complexity are being investigated for their potential use as photocatalysts for water splitting. New photocatalyst candidates based on metal-organic compositions are being developed to engender greater material stability under practical environments in the presence of water and sunlight. The project focuses on a new design of practical multi-electron photocatalyst candidates that can operate in an aqueous instead of organic or mixed organic/aqueous media. The intent is to target water splitting in an efficient, environmentally-responsible manner using catalysts that operate homogeneously, or heterogeneously via solid films in order to increase ruggedness, concentrate the active material, and utilize intermolecular interactions to potentially sensitize cooperative electron transfer. Water solubility, while maintaining high luminescence quantum yield and long phosphorescence lifetime, is a highly desirable attribute for outer-sphere multi-electron photocatalysis. These conditions are satisfied by multiple embodiments of the macromolecular, supramolecular, and nanomolecular complexes that the Omary group is developing in this project in an effort to improve the state of the art of current water splitting photosensitizers. For inner-sphere processes, mono- and multi-nuclear complexes are designed to act as energy reservoirs for 6-12 photoelectrons in some solution compositions, whereas some solid photocatalysts have the potential to provide an almost infinite reservoir of electrons. These hypotheses are being assessed by examining the photophysical, photochemical, and electrochemical properties of complexes possessing ten or eight valence electrons as a function of concentration in solution or doping in thin films vs. the crystalline solid state.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry  (MSN) program of the Chemistry Division, the group of Professor Mohammad Omary of the University of North Texas (UNT) has developed a series of phosphorescent complexes with various molecular- and nano-structural complexity toward their potential use as photocatalysts for water splitting. Besides that primary goal, the project generated fundamental science and new materials that enable other uses such as optical sensors for water remediation (see image 1) and carbon capture from humid exhaust (see image 2). To meet these challenge, new metal-organic compositions have been developed to engender greater material stability under practical environments in presence of water and sunlight. The project has strengthened several existing and/or added other academic/government/industrial collaborations between UNT and other US universities, national laboratories, and private sector entities -- as well as some existing and new international collaborations for the Omary research group on energy-related sciences and technologies.

This project has focused on designing new practical multi-electron photocatalyst candidates that can operate in an aqueous (instead of organic or mixed organic/aqueous media) in order to target water splitting and in an efficient, environmentally-responsible manner with concomitant remediation of toxic metal ions in water. Biocompatible surfactants such as chitosan (derived from shellfish such as shrimp) have allowed these functions to be attainable both homogeneously in aqueous media or heterogeneously via solid films, whereby the latter increase ruggedness, concentrate the active material, and utilize intermolecular interactions to potentially sensitize cooperative electron transfer. Water solubility while maintaining high luminescence quantum yield and long phosphorescence lifetime are highly desirable attributes for outer-sphere multi-electron photocatalysis, and have been attained by embodiments of the metal/organic phosphorescent hybrid compositions (e.g., image 1 among a broad spectrum of macromolecular, supramolecular, and nanomolecular complexes developed in this project. For inner-sphere processes, mono- and multi-nuclear complexes have been designed to act as energy reservoirs for 6-12 photoelectrons in some solution compositions, whereas some solid photocatalysts have the potential to provide an almost infinite reservoir of electrons. Surprising new products have been attained besides those hypothesized to possess the latter feature, including “black absorbers” that overlap with the entire solar spectrum in the ultraviolet and visible regions. Instead of the photoelectron reservoir being due to extended interaction of metal ions with one another, as hypothesized, the new black absorbers enabled that by virtue of interactions of heavy halogens such as iodine in oxidative-addition reaction products of some macrometallocyclic molecular complexes or by virtue of infinite conjugation of linearly-bridging aromatic ligands through metal centers in other coordination polymer solids.

The broader impacts of the project included the training of 100 past and current trainees (35 graduate students, 27 undergraduate students including 7 NSF-REU scholars, 28 high-school students from UNT’s Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science residential early-college-entry program, and 10 postdocs and research or visiting professors, including some from 4-year colleges) from versatile ethnic and race backgrounds. Other measurable impacts included the generation of high-quality/high-quantity (122) scientific products, including the publication of 26 papers in leading journals, the highlighting of representatives thereof on journal covers/scientific highlight journals/multiple agency web sites/etc., 11 patent disclosures, 56 conference presentations, 21 invited seminars, and 8 Ph.D. dissertations since 2014 when the project started. This progress has raised the h-index of the PI to 45 (27 since 2013) and i-10 index to 76 (61 since 2013) with 5600+ total citations (2400+ since 2013).


Last Modified: 03/28/2018
Modified by: Mohammad A Omary

Images (1 of )
  • Omary et al. developed a macrometallocyclic gold complex as a chemosensor capable of detecting and removing silver ions in water at nanomolar/part-per-billion (nM/ppb) levels by a sandwiching mechanism with red-to-green emission color change; other toxic ions are detectable at higher concentrations.
    Brian Squires and Erin Benton
    Mohammad A Omary
    Golden chemosensor of toxic metals
  • Omary et al. investigated carbon capture from humid exhaust whereby carbon emissions that cause climate change are selectively sequestered by a superhydrophobic adsorbent; work done in collaboration with RQ Snurr (Northwestern), X Wang (ORNL), and AK Wilson (Michigan State).
    Iain Oswald
    Public Domain
    Mohammad A Omary
    Carbon capture from humid exhaust
